column6: NY 10075I am smashing all of my previous attempts and futile
column9: and grinding them down with a pestle. If I put all of these remnants into a basin
column10: and it gets taken away from me
column11: then I am no longer responsible for all my misdirected efforts.—Sterling Ruby Gagosian is pleased to present new ceramic sculptures and paintings by Sterling Ruby. In his paintings
column15: Ruby infuses the formal with the abject
column16: allowing materials to melt and overlap in biomorphic and geomorphic aggregations. Ruby’s current exhibition features the largest basins that he has produced to date in the Basin Theology series
column17: as well as figurative and totemic ceramics that recall common artifacts. Ceramic cradles bear an eerie resemblance to graves
column18: evoking the cyclical nature of human life
column19: and otherwise abstract totems stand upright
column20: like soldiers in formation. These deep
column21: textured vessels contain studio remnants and discarded fragments set beneath viscous glazes. Their variegated surfaces feature coloristic effects resulting from different stages of kiln-firing. In the layered glazes that engulf shards of ceramic debris
column24: landscapes appear. Entropy gives rise to an entirely new archeological form.CONTINUE READING… " False text
